So far the largest optimization I have seen is when I
discovered I had typo'd the C3 parameter in the
compatibility function:

(C1*E)+(C2*D)+(C3*W) = compat
E = # excess genes
D = # disjoint genes
W = mena weight delta for like genes

I had initialy had it set to 4.0 instead of 0.4, after
I changed it to the lower value the Avg Generations
went down and it never failed to find a solution
within 100 generations.  When it was set to 4.0, it
failed in about 10% of the cases.


--- Derek James <djames@...> wrote:
> On Fri, 28 May 2004 07:41:11 -0700 (PDT), Karl Lewin
> <lewinke67@...> wrote:
> > 
> > My python implementation seems to be working.
> > 
> > Averages for 100 runs:
> > 
> > Average Generations        : 32.5
> > Average Number of Species  : 19.3 (Targeted to 18)
> > Average Hidden Nodes       :  3.9
> > Average Enabled Connectoins:  9.3
> > 
> > Seems like my average hidden nodes and enabled
> > connections are higher than others have reported. 
> 
> 
> Not necessarily.  In our paper, we reported the
> following stats for
> complexifying NEAT, averaged over 100 runs:
> 
> Average Generations: 44.08
> Average Hidden Nodes:  3.12 
> Average Connections:  11.72 
> 
> So your implementation seems to perform a bit better
> than ours on XOR.  
> 
> Ken's original results for XOR were:
> 
> Average Generations: 32
> Average Hidden Nodes:  2.35 
> Average Connections:  7.48 
> 
> Since there are so many variables, it's difficult to
> tell how to
> optimize.  As Ken has pointed out before, elitism
> can make a
> significant difference in performance, depending on
> how (or whether)
> you're using it.
> 
> I'm not really sure how the different
> implementations compare.  I
> haven't seen such stats on JNEAT or DELPHI NEAT or
> any of the others. 
> Though we did mess around a bit with JNEAT and just
> accepting the
> default parameters for XOR, it did seem to produce
> larger-than-optimal
> networks most of the time.
> 
> If it was a learning exercise, I guess I wouldn't
> worry too much about
> it.  Though it might be interesting to see if you
> can optimize it
> further, and figure out what exactly you had to
> tweak or change to do
> so.
> 
> Derek
>
